title: Comcast, Maybe Apple, Aim To Get Skinny TV Formula Right CMCSA AAPL - Investors.com
text:
W hen Comcast launches a Web-based TV service this fall, first in Boston, it'll be an acid test for another spin of the "skinny bundle" — a lower-priced TV package with limited channels. 
Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL ) will pay attention, analysts say, because its much-anticipated Web-TV service may resemble Comcast's in some ways, if as expected it's launched in 2016. The launch depends on whether Apple can negotiate streaming rights to live broadcast content, as Comcast (NASDAQ: CMCSA ) has done. 
Comcast's $15-per-month Xfinity Stream service will include only the major live broadcast networks — ABC, CBS, NBC and Fox — along with HBO and local TV channels. Comcast's service, which also serves up on-demand content, targets "cord nevers" — young adults who have shunned pay-TV. Sling TV CEO Roger Lynch introduced Dish Network's $20 'skinny' service, Sling TV, at January's Consumer Electronics Show.  View Enlarged Image 

Apple's Web-TV service will likely also target millennials. 
Apple, like Comcast, reportedly wants live or hit programs to anchor its Web offering. 
"The most popular networks, the ones with the biggest audience ratings, are the linchpin of the skinny bundle," Michael Goodman, an analyst at Strategy Analytics, told IBD. 
Skinny TV packages are expected to proliferate as both pay-TV companies and Internet video streamers test new formulas. Each skinny bundle will have its own take on what "must-have" programs should be included. 
Dish Network (NASDAQ: DISH ) targeted "cord nevers" with its $20-per-month Sling service rolled out in January. Dish did not include the four major broadcast networks, opting instead to go with Walt Disney 's (NYSE: DIS ) ESPN and some cable TV channels, mainly from AMC Networks (NASDAQ: AMCX ) and Time Warner (NYSE: TWX ). 
Dish Network had 240,000 Sling customers as of June 30, but is signed up fewer users in Q2 than in Q1. Sony (NYSE: SNE ) also launched a Web-TV service in early 2015, but it hasn't disclosed subscriber numbers. Sony's $50-per-month service packs in more channels than Sling, perhaps because as an outsider to the pay-TV industry, its negotiating position with content companies was weaker, analysts say. 
Even Apple's clout may be suspect, if it wants a $40-per-month service that includes only top networks, while offering other channels in add-on tiers that cost consumers extra. 
"This may not fly with many of the programmers, which will likely lead to Apple having to put more than it wants in the basic tier, pay more for programming, exclude some programmers, set a higher price, or simply give up," said Bryan Kraft, an analyst at Deutsche Bank, in a recent research note. 
While skinny bundles are likely here to stay, not all will pan out.
